sub_subject.name: Media Literacy & Critical Viewing
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Media Literacy & Critical Viewing (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify a commercial.
Name what they are trying to sell.
Identify a logo or slogan.
Identify when someone wants us to join a group.
Name 'Everyone is doing it!' (Bandwagon).
Identify 'Glittering Generalities' (words that sound good but mean nothing).
Identify the title of a story.
Name a scary headline vs. a happy one.
Identify 'Clickbait' (tricking you to click).
Identify words that make us feel mad or sad.
Name 'good guy' and 'bad guy' words.
Identify words that exaggerate.
Identify the 'lesson' of a movie.
Name what the bad guy believes.
Identify when a story makes fun of something good.
Identify happy music vs. scary music in a movie.
Name a 'close-up' on a face.
Identify sound effects (Foley).
Identify a lie vs. a truth.
Name a person we can trust (parent, teacher).
Identify a 'fake news' story (too crazy to be true).
Identify a person on a screen who talks to us.
Name a favorite YouTuber or character.
Identify product placements in videos.
Identify different ways we get stories (Books, TV, Tablet).
Name a newspaper or magazine.
Identify the purpose of a media message (Inform, Persuade, Entertain).
Identify icons for apps (YouTube, etc.).
Name 'sharing' a picture.
Identify the difference between a friend and a follower.
Recall that ads make toys look better than they are.
Observe that ads want our money.
Recall that we should think for ourselves.
Observe posters that tell us what to think.
Recognize 'Card Stacking' (showing only the good side).
Recall that headlines try to grab us.
Observe that different channels show different stories.
Recall that words have power.
Observe when music makes a video feel scary.
Recall that not everyone thinks like us.
Recall that movies are made of many pictures.
Observe colors (bright vs. dark).
Recall that not everything on a screen is true.
Recall that they don't actually know us.
Observe that they want us to watch more.
Recall that some things on screens are real and some are made up.
Observe that TV shows have commercials.
Recall that people can see what we put online.
Observe that people look happy in pictures even if they are sad.
Summarize who the ad is talking to (Target Audience).
Explain how they make you want it (fun music, cool kids).
Explain 'Branding' and identity.
Summarize the Bandwagon technique.
Explain 'Name-Calling' in persuasion.
Explain the use of fear as a motivator.
Defend the necessity of independent thought.
Summarize the main idea of a news headline.
Explain why some stories are chosen and others aren't (Agenda).
Explain the concept of 'Agenda Setting'.
Defend the necessity of reading past the headline.
Summarize how adjectives change the meaning (e.g., 'mob' vs. 'crowd').
Explain how music or pictures manipulate feelings.
Explain 'Connotation' in media language.
Defend the Christian commitment to charitable speech in a polarized age.
Ask 'Is that true?'
Summarize the worldview of a main character.
Explain that movies and shows teach us how to live.
Explain how repetition normalizes ideas (Overton Window).
Defend the Christian worldview against cultural narratives.
Summarize how music tells us how to feel.
Explain a camera angle (looking up makes someone look big/strong).
Explain the 'Kuleshov Effect' (how editing changes meaning).
Defend film as a serious art form comparable to literature.
Ask 'Who said that?'
Summarize why we need to check facts.
Explain that anyone can post on the internet.
Explain Confirmation Bias (believing what we want to be true).
Defend the pursuit of objective truth.
Summarize what an 'Influencer' does (sells things/ideas).
Explain that videos are edited, not real life.
Explain the difference between authority (expertise) and popularity.
Defend the biblical warning against the 'fear of man' (approval addiction).
Summarize the difference between News and Entertainment.
Explain how a book is different from a website.
Explain the decline of print journalism.
Defend the value of deep reading in a skim-reading culture.
Summarize how social media connects people.
Explain what a 'Like' or 'Follow' means.
Explain the concept of 'Virality'.
Defend a biblical view of privacy and modesty online.
Compare the promise in the ad with reality.
Analyze the 'Problem/Solution' format of advertising.
Interpret the lifestyle being sold, not just the product.
Connect consumerism to discontentment.
Defend stewardship against the pressure to consume.
Identify nice words vs. mean words online.
Name the Golden Rule for the internet.
Identify that the computer remembers what we watch.
Name 'Recommended' videos.
Identify the 'Rabbit Hole' effect.
Compare a fact with a persuasion trick.
Analyze wartime or political propaganda posters.
Interpret the use of 'Transfer' (using symbols to borrow authority).
Connect 'Plain Folks' appeal to political campaigns.
Compare two headlines about the same event.
Analyze how the placement of a story (front page vs. back) indicates importance.
Interpret the use of passive voice to hide responsibility in headlines.
Connect story selection to the target audience.
Compare a fact with an emotional opinion.
Analyze the use of Euphemisms (softening reality) and Dysphemisms (hardening reality).
Interpret the rhetorical goal of fear-mongering.
Connect emotional appeals to the bypassing of logic.
Compare the message of a movie with the Bible.
Analyze the underlying assumptions of a news report.
Interpret the 'Narrative' (the story being sold).
Connect media messages to secular humanism or materialism.
Compare a cartoon with a live-action movie.
Analyze the use of lighting (Chiaroscuro) to create mood.
Interpret the composition of a frame (Rule of Thirds).
Connect the editing speed (cuts) to the pacing of the scene.
Compare a trustworthy site (.gov, .edu) with a random site.
Analyze the 'About Us' page of a website.
Interpret the difference between Satire (joke) and Hoax.
Connect 'Lateral Reading' (opening new tabs to check) to verification.
Compare a real teacher with an online star.
Interpret 'Parasocial Relationships' (one-sided friendship).
Connect influencer marketing to consumerism.
Compare watching a movie with reading the book.
Analyze the permanence of print vs. the mutability of digital content.
Interpret the credibility of a published book vs. a blog post.
Connect the medium to the message (how the format changes the content).
Compare talking in person with texting.
Analyze the business model of social media (You are the product).
Interpret the effect of 'curated lives' on self-esteem.
Connect short-form content (TikTok/Reels) to attention span.
Evaluate the ethics of data-driven targeted advertising.
Recall that real people are behind the screen.
Observe that typing in ALL CAPS looks like shouting.
Recall that the computer wants us to keep watching.
Observe that one video leads to another.
Evaluate the fine line between persuasion and manipulation.
Evaluate the impact of sensationalism on truth.
Evaluate the use of 'Virtue Signaling' or 'Dog Whistles'.
Evaluate the subtle injection of ideology into entertainment.
Evaluate the director's use of Mise-en-scne.
Evaluate the credibility of 'Expert' consensus.
Evaluate the authenticity of online personas.
Evaluate Marshall McLuhans concept: 'The Medium is the Message'.
Evaluate the psychological design of gamification in apps.
Construct a deconstruction of a sophisticated ad campaign.
Synthesize the psychological triggers used in marketing.
Analyze the financial incentives behind influencer content.
Summarize the rules of 'Netiquette'.
Explain why bullying online is dangerous.
Explain 'Trolling' and how to handle it (Don't feed the trolls).
Defend the Christian duty to be peacemakers online.
Summarize what an algorithm does (sorts information).
Explain why you see different things than your friend.
Explain the echo chamber effect.
Defend the need for diverse viewpoints for intellectual growth.
Construct an analysis of modern propaganda (memes, viral trends).
Synthesize the history of propaganda from WWI to the present.
Construct a comparative analysis of news coverage from opposing outlets.
Synthesize how framing shapes public perception of reality.
Construct a critique of a partisan editorial.
Synthesize the relationship between language control and thought control (Orwellian concepts).
Construct a worldview analysis of a popular cultural artifact.
Synthesize the concept of 'Cultural Hegemony' (dominant ideas).
Construct a scene analysis of a classic film.
Synthesize visual storytelling techniques to deconstruct a narrative.
Construct a verification protocol for social media claims.
Synthesize the impact of 'Deepfakes' (AI video) on evidence.
Construct a profile of a digital subculture.
Synthesize the shift from institutional trust to personality-based trust.
Construct a comparison of traditional gatekeeping vs. modern self-publishing.
Synthesize the impact of the 24-hour news cycle on public anxiety.
Construct a critique of the 'Attention Economy'.
Synthesize the impact of social media on political polarization.
Compare talking face-to-face with talking online.
Apply the rule: 'Think before you post'.
Analyze the lack of empathy in digital communication.
Interpret the permanence of the Digital Footprint.
Connect online behavior to real-world reputation.
Compare a library (you choose) with a feed (it chooses).
Analyze how algorithms prioritize engagement (anger/fear).
Interpret the 'Filter Bubble' (only seeing what you agree with).
Connect data collection to targeted content.
Evaluate the impact of anonymity on morality.
Evaluate the ethical implications of algorithmic radicalization.
Construct a personal code of ethics for digital engagement.
Synthesize James 3 (taming the tongue) with social media usage.
Construct a strategy to break out of algorithmic curation.
Synthesize the relationship between tech business models and social division.
